Award.AwardTitle: Low-Voltage, Low-Waste Fabrication of Semiconducting Thin Films by Continuous Flow Electrophoretic Deposition

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
One of the most significant impediments to the widespread use of solar energy is the manufacturing cost of the solar cell modules. Electrophoretic deposition, which uses an electric field to drive charged particles to a surface and which is scalable and low cost, presents a compelling solution to this manufacturing problem. This project will study electrophoretic deposition of inorganic semiconducting materials. The objective of this project is to electrophoretically deposit thin films from an ink comprised of nanometer-scale semiconductor crystals dispersed in a solvent. This research could lead to inexpensive, efficient, and sustainable processing methods for manufacturing solar cells from earth-abundant, non-toxic materials. The project will provide graduate and undergraduate students multidisciplinary training in cutting edge nanomanufacturing processes. The research results and accomplishments will be shared at public events, integrated into lectures and lab-based undergraduate courses and brought into the classrooms of a local public school.

The objective of this project is to use colloidal, all-inorganic, nanocrystal dispersions in polar, non-aqueous electrolytes for low-voltage electrophoretic deposition. The hypothesis will be tested that the threshold voltage for electrophoretic deposition can be lowered by an order of magnitude to less than 1 volt under conditions in which electrolysis of the electrolyte is coupled with deposition of the electrophoresing particles. Such low voltages would lead to low deposition rates in conventional reactors. Therefore, a second hypothesis will be tested that continuously flowing the nanocrystal dispersion through an electrophoretic deposition microreactor can achieve both high deposition rate and thick films. Flow rate, reactor geometry, and applied bias can be tuned to achieve near-complete utilization of the nanocrystal feedstock and minimal waste generation. Work will focus on earth-abundant, non-toxic nanocrystals of copper zinc tin sulfide and lead sulfide, which have been used in the highest efficiency quantum dot solar cells. This research will deepen understanding of directed- and self-assembly processes under the influence of applied electric fields, focusing on the poorly understood, non-equilibrium behavior of chemically reactive ions at the intersection of bulk and nanoscale charged surfaces. Specifically it will probe the fundamental mechanism of electrophoretic deposition at low voltage.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

 

One of the most significant impediments to the widespread use of solar energy is the manufacturing cost of the solar cell modules. Electrophoretic deposition (EPD), which uses an electric field to drive charged particles to a surface and which is scalable and low cost, was proposed in this project as a compelling solution to this solar cell manufacturing challenge. However, at the outset, there were many gaps in the understanding of the mechanism of EPD, especially pertaining to the deposition of the non-oxide semiconductors necessary for solar cells. For example, leading theories described this as an electrophysical process, with little consideration of the concurrent electrochemical reactions. A result of this work is that it is now understood which specific electrochemical reactions govern the deposition process. Through rigorous chemical characterization, during and after the EPD synthesis process, minute changes to the atomic composition on the particles' surface as a consequence of EPD are now understood. A novel concept was hereby developed to reduce the required voltage for EPD to occur (the threshold voltage) by the incorporation of rationally designed, electrochemically active additives to the EPD bath. Consequently, it has become possible to reduce the voltage necessary for EPD by an order of magnitude, which is critical to preserving the delicate properties of the resulting semiconductor thin films. The insights learned in depositing materials such as copper zinc tin sulfide, which serve as the material responsible for absorbing sunlight in a solar cell, were applied to the deposition of another class of electronic nanomaterials: two dimensional nanoflakes. With the accomplishment of greatly reduced threshold voltage, a new challenge was revealed: that of efficient mass transport in the assembly of the particles. Here it was demonstrated how laminar flow reactors can be operated to overcome this limitation, and completely utilize the valuable particle starting material.

 

Broader impacts

 

A PhD student, a postdoc and seven undergraduates have received extensive mentoring and development through this research, gaining multidisciplinary training in nanomaterial synthesis, reactor design, materials and device fabrication, electrical testing, and spectroscopy.  This is exemplary preparation for careers in cutting edge materials synthesis and device fabrication. The engineered electrochemical EPD approach demonstrated by this work could form the basis of a scalable manufacturing paradigm for high quality semiconducting thin films, especially for solar cell applications. By rendering solar-cells cost-competitive with fossil fuels, potential benefits could include reduced emission of greenhouse gases, increased domestic energy security, and growth of jobs in America in the development and manufacture of an important high-tech commodity. Relevant to the broader community, the investigators on this project started a program, now in its 4th year, that engages local Philadelphia-area public junior high school students in a hands-on solar powered race-car engineering project. The students learn how to design and build shoe-box sized race cars in teams of two to four, supported by a Drexel engineering undergraduate "advisor" in a series of three Saturday half-day workshops. This program reaches students who are drawn from local area public schools that qualify for free lunch programs, and are unlikely to encounter hands-on engineering experiences in their regular curriculum. This project aims to educate the students about solar power and inspire them to pursue engineering and STEM opportunities in the future. As a culmination of these efforts, we now have partnered with a national organization (Junior Solar Sprint) to host an annual regional competition for racing these student-built solar powered cars with over 200 junior-high aged participants every year.
